mn88:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn88:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn88:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn88:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

mn88:2.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena pubbārāmo migāramātupāsādo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
mn88:2.2.eng: He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, for the day’s meditation.

mn88:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo ekapuṇḍarīkaṃ nāgaṃ abhiruhitvā sāvatthiyā niyyāti divā divassa.
mn88:3.1.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala mounted the Single Lotus Elephant and drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day.
mn88:3.1.comm: “Single lotus” (ekapuṇḍarīka) appears as an auspicious epithet in a prayer for wealth at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.3.6.

mn88:3.2.pli: Addasā kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn88:3.2.eng: He saw Ānanda coming off in the distance

mn88:3.3.eng: and said to the chief minister Sirivaḍḍha,
mn88:3.3.comm: Different persons of the same name appear in SN 47.29 and Thag 1.41.

mn88:3.4.eng: “My dear Sirivaḍḍha, isn’t that Venerable Ānanda?”

mn88:4.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
mn88:4.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi addressed a man,

mn88:4.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn88:4.2.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Ānanda, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

mn88:4.3.pli: ‘rājā, bhante, pasenadi kosalo āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti;
mn88:4.3.eng: ‘Sir, King Pasenadi of Kosala bows with his head at your feet.’

mn88:4.5.pli: ‘sace kira, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa na kiñci accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ, āgametu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando muhuttaṃ anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
mn88:4.5.eng: ‘Sir, if you have no urgent business, please wait an hour out of sympathy.’”

mn88:5.1.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho so puriso rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so puriso āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
mn88:5.1.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” that man replied. He did as the king asked.

mn88:5.2.pli: “rājā, bhante, pasenadi kosalo āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandati;

mn88:5.4.pli: ‘sace kira, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa na kiñci accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ, āgametu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando muhuttaṃ anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

mn88:6.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā nāgā paccorohitvā pattikova yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
mn88:6.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Ānanda on foot. He bowed, stood to one side, and said to Ānanda,

mn88:6.3.pli: “sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa na kiñci accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ, sādhu, bhante, āyasmā ānando yena aciravatiyā nadiyā tīraṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
mn88:6.3.eng: “Sir, if you have no urgent business, it would be nice of you to go to the bank of the Aciravatī river out of sympathy.”

mn88:7.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena aciravatiyā nadiyā tīraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn88:7.2.eng: He went to the river bank and sat at the root of a certain tree on a seat spread out.

mn88:7.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā nāgā paccorohitvā pattikova yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
mn88:7.3.eng: Then King Pasenadi rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Ānanda on foot. He bowed, stood to one side, and said to Ānanda,

mn88:7.4.eng: “Here, Venerable Ānanda, sit on this elephant rug.”

mn88:7.7.eng: I’m sitting on my own seat.”

mn88:8.1.pli: Nisīdi kho rājā pasenadi kosalo paññatte āsane.
mn88:8.1.eng: So the king sat down on the seat spread out,

mn88:8.2.pli: Nisajja kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:

mn88:8.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā tathārūpaṃ kāyasamācāraṃ samācareyya, yvāssa kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehī”ti?
mn88:8.3.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, would the Buddha engage in the sort of behavior—by way of body, speech, or mind—that is faulted by ascetics and brahmins?”
mn88:8.3.comm: The commentary says that Pasenadi’s actions were occasioned by the brutal murder of the wanderer Sundarī. Unscrupulous ascetics urged her to visit the Jeta Grove, then killed her so that blame would fall on the Buddha and his community (Ud 8.4). However, nothing in this sutta or its parallel at MA 214 supports this connection.

mn88:8.4.pli: “Na kho, mahārāja, so bhagavā tathārūpaṃ kāyasamācāraṃ samācareyya, yvāssa kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
mn88:8.4.eng: “No, great king, the Buddha would not engage in the sort of behavior that is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

mn88:8.5.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā tathārūpaṃ vacīsamācāraṃ …pe…

mn88:8.6.pli: manosamācāraṃ samācareyya, yvāssa manosamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehī”ti?

mn88:8.7.pli: “Na kho, mahārāja, so bhagavā tathārūpaṃ manosamācāraṃ samācareyya, yvāssa manosamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.

mn88:9.2.pli: Yañhi mayaṃ, bhante, nāsakkhimhā pañhena paripūretuṃ taṃ, bhante, āyasmatā ānandena pañhassa veyyākaraṇena paripūritaṃ.
mn88:9.2.eng: For I couldn’t fully express the question, but Venerable Ānanda’s answer completed it for me.
mn88:9.2.comm: Ānanda completed Pasenadi’s phrasing by adding “sensible” (viññūhi), since the Buddha’s conduct was in fact faulted by foolish ascetics and brahmins.

mn88:9.3.pli: Ye te, bhante, bālā abyattā ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā paresaṃ vaṇṇaṃ vā avaṇṇaṃ vā bhāsanti, na mayaṃ taṃ sārato paccāgacchāma;
mn88:9.3.eng: I don’t believe that praise or criticism of others spoken by incompetent fools, without examining or scrutinizing, is the most important thing.

mn88:9.4.pli: ye pana te, bhante, paṇḍitā viyattā medhāvino anuvicca pariyogāhetvā paresaṃ vaṇṇaṃ vā avaṇṇaṃ vā bhāsanti, mayaṃ taṃ sārato paccāgacchāma.
mn88:9.4.eng: Rather, I believe that praise or criticism of others spoken by competent and intelligent people after examining and scrutinizing is the most important thing.

mn88:10.1.pli: Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti?
mn88:10.1.eng: But Honorable Ānanda, what kind of bodily behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?”
mn88:10.1.comm: This passage describes bad actions from five perspectives, showing that the Buddha’s analysis of morality was not based on a single factor.

mn88:10.2.comm: “Unskillful” (akusala) is an unwholesome quality of the mind, so this is the psychological dimension of immorality. What is unskillful is that which leads to the result opposite to that desired: we want happiness, but it leads to suffering.

mn88:10.3.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior is unskillful?”

mn88:10.4.comm: “Blameworthy” (sāvajja) behavior is that which makes one liable to criticism by others. This is the social dimension of immorality.

mn88:10.5.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior is blameworthy?”

mn88:10.6.comm: “Hurtful” (sabyābajjha) refers to the fact that bad conduct is characterized by hurtful affliction both in its action and its consequences.

mn88:10.7.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior is hurtful?”

mn88:10.8.comm: “Results in suffering” (dukkhavipāka) through painful kammic consequences in this life or the future.

mn88:10.9.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior results in suffering?”

mn88:10.10.pli: “Yo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro attabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati.
mn88:10.10.eng: “Bodily behavior that leads to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both,
mn88:10.10.comm: Bad conduct does not just affect oneself, but reverberates in space, by harming others, and in time, by promoting the growth of even more unskillful qualities.

mn88:10.11.pli: Tassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
mn88:10.11.eng: and which makes unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn88:10.12.pli: evarūpo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
mn88:10.12.eng: That kind of bodily behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

mn88:11.2.eng: mental behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?” …

mn88:12.4.pli: “Yo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro attabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati.
mn88:12.4.eng: “Mental behavior that leads to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both,

mn88:12.5.pli: Tassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
mn88:12.5.eng: and which makes unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn88:12.6.pli: evarūpo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
mn88:12.6.eng: That kind of mental behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

mn88:13.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā sabbesaṃyeva akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ vaṇṇetī”ti?
mn88:13.1.eng: “Sir, does the Buddha praise giving up all these unskillful things?”

mn88:13.2.eng: “Great king, the Realized One has given up all unskillful things and possesses skillful things.”

mn88:14.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, kāyasamācāro anopārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti?
mn88:14.1.eng: “But sir, what kind of bodily behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?”
mn88:14.1.comm: The analysis is inverted for good conduct.

mn88:14.3.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior is skillful?”

mn88:14.5.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior is blameless?”

mn88:14.7.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior is pleasing?”

mn88:14.9.eng: “But what kind of bodily behavior results in happiness?”

mn88:14.10.pli: “Yo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro nevattabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, na parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati.
mn88:14.10.eng: “Bodily behavior that leads to pleasing yourself, pleasing others, and pleasing both,

mn88:14.11.pli: Tassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn88:14.11.eng: and which makes unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn88:14.12.pli: Evarūpo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro anopārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
mn88:14.12.eng: That kind of bodily behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

mn88:15.2.eng: mental behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?” …

mn88:16.6.pli: “Yo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro nevattabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, na parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattati.
mn88:16.6.eng: “Mental behavior that leads to pleasing yourself, pleasing others, and pleasing both,

mn88:16.7.pli: Tassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn88:16.7.eng: and which makes unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn88:16.8.pli: Evarūpo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro anopārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
mn88:16.8.eng: That kind of mental behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

mn88:17.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā sabbesaṃyeva kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ vaṇṇetī”ti?
mn88:17.1.eng: “Sir, does the Buddha praise embracing all these skillful things?”

mn88:17.2.eng: “Great king, the Realized One has given up all unskillful things and possesses skillful things.”
mn88:17.2.comm: Ānanda emphasizes that the Buddha does not just praise these things, he embodies them fully.

mn88:18.2.eng: How well this was said by Venerable Ānanda!

mn88:18.3.pli: Iminā ca mayaṃ, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa subhāsitena attamanābhiraddhā.
mn88:18.3.eng: I’m delighted and satisfied with what you’ve expressed so well.

mn88:18.4.pli: Evaṃ attamanābhiraddhā ca mayaṃ, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa subhāsitena.

mn88:18.5.pli: Sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa hatthiratanaṃ kappeyya, hatthiratanampi mayaṃ āyasmato ānandassa dadeyyāma.
mn88:18.5.eng: if an elephant-treasure was suitable for you, I would give you one.

mn88:18.6.pli: Sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa assaratanaṃ kappeyya, assaratanampi mayaṃ āyasmato ānandassa dadeyyāma.
mn88:18.6.eng: If a horse-treasure was suitable for you, I would give you one.

mn88:18.7.pli: Sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa gāmavaraṃ kappeyya, gāmavarampi mayaṃ āyasmato ānandassa dadeyyāma.
mn88:18.7.eng: If a prize village was suitable for you, I would give you one.

mn88:18.9.eng: these things are not suitable for you.

mn88:18.10.pli: Ayaṃ me, bhante, bāhitikā raññā māgadhena ajātasattunā vedehiputtena vatthanāḷiyā pakkhipitvā pahitā soḷasasamā āyāmena, aṭṭhasamā vitthārena.
mn88:18.10.eng: This imported cloth was sent to me by King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, packed in a parasol case. It’s exactly sixteen measures long and eight wide.
mn88:18.10.comm: The Chinese parallel at MA 214 has 繖, which supports the reading chatta (“parasol”). | For bāhitikā, I accept the commentary’s explanation that it means “foreign” or “imported” (cf. Sanskrit bāhya).

mn88:18.11.pli: Taṃ, bhante, āyasmā ānando paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
mn88:18.11.eng: May Venerable Ānanda please accept it out of sympathy.”

mn88:18.12.eng: “Enough, great king. My three robes are complete.”

mn88:19.1.pli: “Ayaṃ, bhante, aciravatī nadī diṭṭhā āyasmatā ceva ānandena amhehi ca.
mn88:19.1.eng: “Sir, we have both seen this river Aciravatī

mn88:19.2.pli: Yadā uparipabbate mahāmegho abhippavuṭṭho hoti, athāyaṃ aciravatī nadī ubhato kūlāni saṃvissandantī gacchati;
mn88:19.2.eng: when it has rained heavily in the mountains, and the river overflows both its banks.

mn88:19.3.pli: evameva kho, bhante, āyasmā ānando imāya bāhitikāya attano ticīvaraṃ karissati.
mn88:19.3.eng: In the same way, Venerable Ānanda can make a set of three robes for himself from this imported cloak,

mn88:19.4.pli: Yaṃ panāyasmato ānandassa purāṇaṃ ticīvaraṃ taṃ sabrahmacārīhi saṃvibhajissati.
mn88:19.4.eng: and you can share your old robes with your fellow monks.

mn88:19.5.pli: Evāyaṃ amhākaṃ dakkhiṇā saṃvissandantī maññe gamissati.
mn88:19.5.eng: In this way my religious donation will come to overflow, it seems to me.

mn88:20.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
mn88:20.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi said to him,

mn88:20.3.pli: “handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bhante ānanda, gacchāma;

mn88:20.4.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

mn88:20.5.eng: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”

mn88:20.6.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmato ānandassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
mn88:20.6.eng: Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what Ānanda said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Ānanda, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

mn88:21.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando acirapakkantassa rañño pasenadissa kosalassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn88:21.1.eng: Soon after he left, Ānanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,

mn88:21.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando yāvatako ahosi raññā pasenadinā kosalena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
mn88:21.2.eng: and told him what had happened.

mn88:21.3.eng: He presented the cloth to the Buddha.

mn88:22.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

mn88:22.2.pli: “lābhā, bhikkhave, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa, suladdhalābhā, bhikkhave, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa;
mn88:22.2.eng: “Mendicants, King Pasenadi is lucky, so very lucky,

mn88:22.3.pli: yaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo labhati ānandaṃ dassanāya, labhati payirupāsanāyā”ti.
mn88:22.3.eng: to get to see Ānanda and pay homage to him.”

mn88:22.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn88:22.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn88:22.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
